bankruptcy act 1966 (cth), ss. 60 , 116 . in 1974 the applicant commenced an action in the high court against the commonwealth of australia and one brigadier flint. in december 1975 she filed a statement of claim alleging damages totalling $1,246,000 arising out of the negligent advice or misrepresentation of the defendants. on 15th march, 1978, a sequestration order was made against the applicant; the respondent was the trustee of her estate. on 14th november, 1980, the applicant filed an application seeking, inter alia, two declarations: (a) that she might continue in her own name the high court action; (b) that the provisions of s. 116 (2) (g) of the bankruptcy act 1966 applied to her right to recover damages in the high court action.
bankruptcy
application for leave to appeal from interlocutory judgment
right of a bankrupt to issue proceedings
s116 of bankruptcy act 1966
action not in relation to personal injuries or wrongs
severance of actions
hopeless claims
leave to appeal refused

citances.sentence: In Rana v Musolino [2009] FCA 1050 , Finn J concluded that the applicant could not challenge the Trustee's decision to discontinue the proceeding in the High Court, because the cause of action relied upon was not one for damages for personal injury or wrong done to him so as to fall within the compass of s 60(4) and 116 (2)(g) of the Act. The first claim is for a declaration that the applicant has the right to seek special leave to appeal from the High Court of Australia in respect of the decision of McKerracher J in Rana v Musolino [2010] FCA 476. The character of the proceeding about which the applicant seeks to invoke the jurisdiction of the High Court has already been decided by Finn J in Rana v Musolino [2009] FCA 1050 and affirmed by McKerracher J in Rana v Musolino [2010] FCA 476. The applicant is attempting to have those decisions reviewed through a back door. Moreover, he has not gone any distance at all to show that those decisions are erroneous.

Accordingly the Master was not satisfied that the plaintiff was claiming for personal injury severed from the plaintiff's property rights which were legitimately the entitlements of his creditors. [18] In addition it involves the complex question of the right of an undischarged bankrupt to claim, after his bankruptcy, for "personal injury without reference to his rights of property". [10] The history of the litigation The subject proceedings were issued on 2 May 2003, namely after the sequestration order was made. The accompanying Statement of Claim was grossly inadequate. The defendants sought an order that the plaintiff's claim be dismissed on the bases that the Statement of Claim did not disclose an arguable cause of action; that it was statute barred; and that the defendants were immune from any such cause of action. HELD: appeal dismissed. Bankrupty Act 1966 (Cwth) s58(1)(a); District Court Act 1991 s24 , s 43 (2)(a); District Court Rules 1987 rr3.01, 3.04 and 46.18, referred to. Cox v Journeaux (No 2) (1935) [1935] HCA 48 ; 52 CLR 713 ; Rana v Musolino [2010] FCA 476 ; [2009] FCA 1050 , applied. AON Risk Services Aust Ltd v Anu (2009) 239 CLR 175 ; Queensland v J L Holdings [1997] HCA 1 ; (1997) 189 CLR 146 ; Johnson v Public Trustee Queensland [2010] QCA 260 ; Beverage Bottlers (SA) Ltd (In Liq) v Abode Enterprises Pty Ltd [2009] SASC 272 ; BQ & HM Doe Pty Ltd v National Aust Bank [1999] SASC 124 ; Daemar v Industrial Commission of NSW & Ors 91998) 12 NSWLR 45 ; Nguyen ex parte Official Trustee (1992) 32 FCR 320 ; Official Trustee in Bankruptcy As Trustee of the Bankrupt Estate of Andrew Ley Jordan v Maria Lucia Jordan [2004] SADC 173 ; Badcock v Price Waterhouse Coopers (Reg) & Anor [2006] SADC 101 ; Badcock v State of South Australia & Ors [2008] SADC 133 ; Badcock v Pirie Street Holdings [2010] FCA 627 at [23] and [2010] FCA 628 ; Lauro v The Marble House of Aust [2010] SASC 211 , considered. BADCOCK v STATE OF SOUTH AUSTRALIA & ORS [2010] SADC 147
Introduction This is an appeal by Robert John Badcock, ("the plaintiff"), from certain orders made by a Master of this Court on 10 February 2009.
